title: Kenya: Sliding Shilling Tops List of Worries for Businesses - Stanchart
text:
Kenya: Firm Defends Airport Buses Import Deal 
This pushed the overall BSI to 58.6 in June from 66.9 in May, a 12.4 per cent month on month decline. 
Ten out of 15 current indicators on the business environment slipped, with 'order backlogs' and the 'effect of the shilling exchange rate' indicators both falling below the key 50 level. 
SLIPPED IN JUNE 
Further, many indicators related to demand, including new orders and export orders, slipped in June. An indicator below 50 indicates a contraction. A result of 50 means no change. Despite softening in business activity, businesses remained optimistic about near-term prospects. 
Eleven of the 15 future expectation indicators increased in June compared to May, when 13 future expectation indicators declined. 
Each month, up to 200 formal-sector businesses in different sectors in Kenya respond to questions on the country's current and future economic conditions. 
StanChart indicates that although most of the respondents polled are Nairobi-based, with some in Mombasa, businesses that they represent are active across Kenya. 
Respondents are asked whether business activity has increased, decreased, or remained the same, compared with the previous month. They are also asked about their expectations over the next quarter. An indicator above 50 shows an expansion. 
"Businesses are concerned about rising imbalances, a depreciating exchange rate and the potential need for more tightening to stabilise the Kenyan shilling," StanChart's chief Africa economist, Razia Khan, said. 
The shilling, which has depreciated by about 9 per cent to the dollar, opened trading today 99.20/30 to the greenback. The shilling has come under pressure from high demand for dollars by importers, declining forex inflows from key earners such as tourism, coffee and tea. Kenya
